text: hi everyone hush danny grimtano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new mastodon
album hushed and grim yes this is the
eighth full-length lp from legendary
sledge metal outfit mastodon a band i
hope needs no intro at this point since
they've had about as much influence on
modern metal as one band can but
interestingly hushton grim makes for the
band's first double album with 15 tracks
and almost 90 minutes of material which
did have me a little freaked considering
the state of the band's last record say
what you will about emperor of sans
survival and mortality concept
instrumentally and compositionally i
still found the record to be less than
sufficient with the band watering down
their sludgy and progressive style with
notes of alt metal and alt-rock some of
their weakest and weirdest vocal
performances to day two but in a way i
see this new record as a part of a
larger pendulum swing that's been going
on in the band's discography over the
past decade as at one point we had the
band taking a much simpler and more
direct approach with their sound on the
hunter which was then followed by the
much more thorough and solid once more
around the sun and now after emperor of
sand the band is hitting us with this
heavy somewhat psychedelic prague sludge
odyssey with lots of sprawling verses
solo passages and builds i wouldn't say
hushed and grim is a night and day
difference in terms of sound and style
when comparing it to any of mastodon's
previous works i mean given the band's
progressive pedigree we shouldn't be
surprised to hear them drop in a sci-fi
spooky synth solo on the back end of
skeleton of splendor or suddenly
breaking into this vaguely south asian
drone in the second half of dagger like
with emperor of sand the band is trying
out some new stuff here and there but
i'm happy to report that this time
around the risks that mastodon takes on
hushton grimm for the most part come
across sensible and tasteful there are
loads of tracks on this thing that feel
like classic mastodon all the way but
with more of a chilling melancholic edge
like pain with an anchor which features
some really grim guitar leads heavy
drums and bass lots of dramatic soaring
cleans topping that which contrasts
really well with the more thunderous
passages of the song the whole thing
feels like being trapped in a
purgatorial nightmare with pain and
grief and suffering being turned into
medicine then there's the even heavier
crux whose crushing choruses are
absolutely perfect for these refrains of
i
feel
pressure
the sound of this track as usual with
mastodon is thick it's muscular the
vocals bellow as if i'm hearing zeus
calling down from the clouds following
the first third of this lp though the
band begins to shake things up
instrumentally and as a result of that
stuff can go either way skeleton of
splendor i mentioned earlier is another
attempt of the band to make a metallica
style ballad but maybe with a more eerie
approach the tune's not bad and i like
the attempt overall but the mix and
sound of this track is so drony and
bassy it kind of takes away from the
finesse of the performance then there's
the even clumsier the beast whose
guitars sound like a cross between uh
country prague sludge the song honest to
god sounds like chris stapleton with a
horrendous effect on his voice singing
with opeth as the backing band at
shotgun point so yeah not that great but
by that same token we do get the song
tier drinker one of the band's catchiest
and most anthemic songs ever with the
sweet and sinister guitar leads as well
as mid-paced grooves the song almost has
like a gothic quality to it which i like
a lot there's something sort of campy
about it as well that reminds me of a
song ghost would write and again i mean
in a good way because i think mastodon
does a great job of kind of making these
elements work for their sound pushing
the tides is the record's first true
blue ass kicker totally relentless
performance is killer it's just a shame
that the mix is a little out of whack
the drums are so
aggressively uh placed on this one the
toms and kick especially kind of
overtake everything else still the riffs
on this track are absolutely disgusting
and the way the band works in some of
these trippy synth leads here and there
is great peace and tranquility isn't a
bad melodic number either it has these
uh clean style vocals that kind of smack
of 80s era ozzy osbourne the song also
undergoes a couple of pretty cool groove
and riff changes dagger i mentioned
earlier does have that cool aesthetic
and stylistic change of pace uh really
sort of transports you to another part
of the world in a way but i wish it had
a stronger ending even if the abrupt
finish it undergoes kind of plays into
the narrative of the lyrics savage lands
brings another killer cut into the mix
but then gobblers of dregs the longest
cut on this lp is long-winded in
absolutely the worst way which is weird
because the track just has an eight
minute run time not really that long by
prague standards the band has written
longer songs than this that are more
engaging from front to back but yeah the
epic intro on this thing kind of melts
quickly into this slo-mo metal ballad
with tons of washed out vocals the
second half of the track undergoes an
awkward groove switch with these delayed
rhythm guitars like u2's the edge is
popped into the studio to do backup and
this isn't the only longer song on this
record that for whatever reason is kind
of a dud their sickle and peace which
has some of the most tedious verses on
the entire lp the grooves on this track
are so damn stiff and the verse vocals
are just going nowhere fast then eyes of
serpents oddly enough feels like a heavy
take on maybe a medieval ballad of some
sort in three four i do like the
pronounced ascending and descending
vocal melodies of the track and i
typically
do find favor with a lot of folk
inspired metal but once more this is a
track whose blaring instrumentation kind
of crushes the ballad at the core of the
song the ending of the record was
definitely a highlight too a truly
righteous finish for the project but
overall i don't know if doing a longer
record was the best idea this time
around for mastodon because it's not
like these tracks and their narratives
at least you know in my opinion uh
coalesced into this like really grand
and epic experience for the most part
the track list here just ended up
feeling a little bloated and somewhat
lacking in variation don't get me wrong
the band does take some risks and works
in some extra bits of instrumentation
here and there but given this record
again is almost 90 minutes they
certainly could have pushed that further
i'm not in love with the record and
people who aren't already mastodon fans
may have a hard time getting into this
very hefty and winding project still
it's a much more consistent robust and
impressive offering than emperor of sand
was feeling a light to decent six on
this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video that you
can check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
music
mastodon
of forever
